author: By Jonathan Weisman and Robert Jimison
title: Boebert Opts Out of Special Election to Focus on Primary in a New District
description: Lauren Boebert’s decision will protect the House Republicans’ razor-thin majority, but it could make her pursuit of the new seat more challenging.
content: Representative Lauren Boebert, the firebrand Republican from Colorado, said on Wednesday she will not resign her current seat even though the seat she ultimately wants is now being vacated by her House colleague, Ken Buck, sooner than she expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari, David McCabe and Annie Karni
title: House Passes Bill to Force TikTok Sale From Chinese Owner or Ban the App
description: The legislation received wide bipartisan support, with both Republicans and Democrats showing an eagerness to appear tough on China.
content: The House on Wednesday passed a bill with broad bipartisan support that would force TikTok’s Chinese owner to either sell the hugely popular video app or have it banned in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabby Sobelman, Adam Sella and Cassandra Vinograd
title: Israel’s Justice Ministry Opens Inquiry Into Police Killing of Youth in East Jerusalem
description: The Israeli police said they fired in response to a firework shot directly at them. The Palestinian news agency said the boy was 13, while the Jerusalem hospital where he was pronounced dead said he was 12.
content: Israel’s justice ministry said Wednesday it was questioning an officer who fatally shot a youth accused of shooting a firework at security forces in East Jerusalem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: After Testy Interview With Elon Musk, Don Lemon Says His Deal With X Is Canceled
description: Days before the former television anchor’s new talk show debuted, his deal combusted after an interview with the site’s owner, he said.
content: In the wake of a testy interview with Elon Musk, the former television anchor Don Lemon’s deal for a new talk show on X combusted just days before it was scheduled to air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Jen Poyant, Paula Szuchman, Kate LoPresti, Daniel Ramirez, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker and Marion Lozano
title: Brittany Howard Sings Through the Pangs of New Love
description: On her second solo record since leaving Alabama Shakes, “What Now,” Brittany Howard traces a path out of heartbreak. Today, she reads a Modern Love essay about that treacherous, hopeful journey back to love.
content: Brittany Howard, the five-time Grammy Award-winning singer, makes vibrant, dynamic music about love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A Ban? A Sale? The Big Questions Hanging Over TikTok
description: The popular app could be banned in the U.S. unless its Chinese parent divests. There’s a growing debate on whether that’s even possible.
content: The House is set to vote on Wednesday on a bill that would ostensibly present ByteDance, the Chinese owner of TikTok, with an ultimatum: sell TikTok’s U.S. operations, or have the app barred.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: ‘What American Families Experienced Is Not Something That You Get Over’
description: Four years after the pandemic began, parents continue to struggle with a broken child care system, but there’s reason to hope for a better future.
content: A few weeks ago, I got a panicked message from Jason Cohen, a dad in upstate New York. He told me that the day care where his twin toddlers had been happily ensconced for over a year, J.A.C.E. Daycare and Early Learning Center in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., was closing unexpectedly and had given parents less than two weeks’ notice and no clear explanation. But Mid Hudson News reported that the center was “suffering extreme financial stress and defaulted on a major loan.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Len Sirowitz, Whose Bold, Offbeat Ads Captured an Era, Dies at 91
description: An award-winning agency art director, he brought a striking visual touch to campaigns for the Volkswagen Beetle, Sara Lee and Sony in the ’60s as well as to the antiwar and antinuclear movements.
content: Len Sirowitz, an award-winning advertising art director whose creative work in the 1960s included memorable print ads for the Volkswagen Beetle — like one declaring, “Ugly is only skin-deep” — and a campaign for Mobil in which a car was dropped off a 10-story building to make a point about the perils of speeding, died on March 4 at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: ‘Illinoise’: A Place of Overflowing Emotion, but Little Dance Spirit
description: Justin Peck, who directs and choreographs a narrative dance musical to Sufjan Stevens’s concept album “Illinois,” resorts to his usual standby: community.
content: “They trust themselves more than actors do,” Jerome Robbins once wrote of dancers. “Dancers know they will make it their own. Actors have the complication of wanting to make it their own, and their horror of exposing what their own is. Dancers always reveal themselves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Lessons From Abroad on How Biden Can Win
description: Incumbents are unpopular in all Western democracies, but there may be ways to allay the angst driving voter dissatisfaction.
content: As Democrats puzzle over how President Biden can be so unpopular, it’s worth looking at the global context — because he’s actually doing better than most Western leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaj Larsen
title: What the ‘Rust’ Shooting Case Is Really About
description: The conviction of a “Rust” crew member in a tragic on-set death highlights what Hollywood must do to avoid fatal accidents in the future.
content: In my first job as a military adviser on a film set, I witnessed the stark contrast between the gun safety culture of my Navy SEAL days and the cavalier attitude toward firearms that permeates Hollywood. During a break in filming, the lead actor, fresh off a stint as a teen heartthrob, picked up a gun and began waving it around, joking with the cast. Instinctively, I leaped toward the actor, grabbed the gun and gave him a hard thump to the chest, admonishing him for “flagging” the entire crew — using the military term for aiming a firearm at someone.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tate McRae, Dua Lipa and the Fight to Be ‘Main Pop Girl’
description: A conversation about a title that emerged from stan communities, and how it’s played a role in pop singers’ careers.
content: Over the past few years, one question has been hovering over the careers of some of the most well-known pop singers in the world: Have they reached the tier of Main Pop Girl?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: A Vote Targeting TikTok and an Unexpected Win for Ukraine
description: Plus, dating apps are feeling rejected.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: In Silicon Valley, Venture Capital Meets a Generational Shift
description: Big-name investors such as Reid Hoffman and Michael Moritz are pulling back, creating room for a new generation of tech power brokers.
content: Reid Hoffman, a founder of LinkedIn and a longtime venture capitalist, is no longer the public face of the venture firm Greylock. Michael Moritz, a force at Sequoia Capital for 38 years, officially separated from the investment firm last summer. And Jeff Jordan, a top investor at Andreessen Horowitz for 12 years, left in May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Dave Philipps, Jessica Cheung, Clare Toeniskoetter, Olivia Natt, Sydney Harper, M.J. Davis Lin, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The Alarming Findings Inside a Mass Shooter’s Brain
description: An attack by an Army reservist prompted a search for answers about whether the soldier’s service could have been a factor.
content: Warning: this episode contains descriptions of violence and self harm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Reddit’s Long, Rocky Road to an Initial Public Offering
description: The site, a throwback to an earlier era of social media, is poised to go public as soon as next week. It hasn’t been easy to reach this point.
content: During a leadership crisis in 2015, Reddit asked Steve Huffman, one of its founders, to return to run the social media platform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison
title: Ken Buck Cuts Short House Term, Leaving Republicans Down Yet Another Member
description: The Colorado Republican, who announced his retirement last fall, said he would leave Congress at the end of next week, further shrinking his party’s already minuscule majority.
content: Representative Ken Buck, Republican of Colorado, announced on Tuesday that he would leave Congress at the end of next week, cutting short his final term in office in a move that will further shrink his party’s already tiny majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A Finance Reporter Who Invests in Readers’ Well-Being
description: Taxes. Tuition. Cryptocurrency trading. Since 2008, Ron Lieber has answered hard-hitting questions about personal finance as the Your Money columnist.
content: When Ron Lieber arrived at The Wall Street Journal’s office in 2002 for a job interview, a couple of editors immediately sized him up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Yvonne Loriod Was So Much More Than a Composer’s Muse
description: Loriod, the vessel for Olivier Messiaen’s piano works, had a rich musical life beyond him, which is captured in a new set of recordings.
content: The composer Olivier Messiaen’s earliest students at the Paris Conservatory liked to call themselves the Arrows. They didn’t see themselves as mere pupils; with the help of their teacher, one of the most important voices in 20th-century French music, they imagined themselves shooting arrows into the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Judge Quashes Six Charges in Georgia Election Case Against Trump
description: The ruling said charges that Donald Trump and allies solicited public officials to break the law were not specific enough; it left the rest of the case intact.
content: In a surprise move on Wednesday, a judge in Atlanta quashed six of the charges against former President Donald J. Trump and his allies in the sprawling Georgia election interference case, including one related to a call that Mr. Trump made to pressure Georgia’s secretary of state in early January 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fortesa Latifi
title: You Texted? I Hadn’t Noticed.
description: “Do Not Disturb” mode lets smartphone users silence notifications — and signals that they may take a while to respond.
content: Annie Wu Henry hasn’t gotten a notification on her phone in two years. Calls go straight to voice mail. Apps vibrate their updates into the ether. Texts pile up silently. Same with emails. They have to wait until she decides to look at her device next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: A Blood Test Shows Promise for Early Colon Cancer Detection
description: Many patients are reluctant to undergo colonoscopies or conduct at-home fecal tests. Doctors see potential in another screening method.
content: Early detection of colon cancer can prevent a majority of deaths from this disease, possibly as much as 73 percent of them. But just 50 to 75 percent of middle-aged and older adults who should be screened regularly are being tested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Hunter Biden Refuses to Testify Publicly, Calling G.O.P. Inquiry a ‘Circus’
description: In a letter, a lawyer for the president’s son cited a scheduling conflict and denounced the Republican impeachment inquiry as a “carnival side show.”
content: Hunter Biden, the president’s son, on Wednesday rejected a request from House Republicans to testify next week at a public hearing in their impeachment inquiry into President Biden, blasting the G.O.P.’s plans as a “made-for-right-wing-media circus act.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence A. Rosenwald
title: A Provocative New Biography of Emerson Focuses on the Man
description: In “Glad to the Brink of Fear,” James Marcus frames the great Transcendentalist as a writer for our times.
content: James Marcus’s new biography of the great Transcendentalist writer, lecturer and thinker Ralph Waldo Emerson opens with a sharp contrast. On the one hand, Marcus writes, there is Emerson as he is portrayed by others, the “irritating uncle at the feast of American letters,” the “cheerleader for the most conformist aspects of American life.” Then, there is Emerson as he truly is: the “great apostle of nonconformity,” and “anything but a Victorian relic.” Marcus proposes to portray the latter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexa Brazilian and Kyoko Hamada
title: How Crudités Became an Art Form
description: Blessed with an ever-widening array of fancy heirloom produce, chefs are turning uncooked vegetables into edible sculptures.
content: The New York-based private chef Yann Nury has a simple strategy for transforming unadorned produce into showstopping canapés. “It’s all about finding the most unique vegetable,” says the 40-year-old Frenchman, “and making it a star.” At the events he caters for clients, shiny orange Sungold tomatoes masquerade as gumballs in Austrian crystal candy dishes; vivid green sugar snap peas fill sterling silver punch bowls; and perfectly polished radishes, cucumbers and petite carrots are presented atop toasted rye crumbs arranged to resemble the garden soil in which they were grown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Mark Landler
title: U.K. Moves to Bar Foreign State Ownership of Newspapers, a Blow to Telegraph Bid
description: A roughly $1 billion bid from the former CNN chief Jeff Zucker and his Emirati backers raised concerns among lawmakers over a storied conservative newspaper.
content: An audacious effort by the American media executive Jeff Zucker and his Emirati backers to acquire London’s Daily Telegraph appeared to be on life support on Wednesday after the British government advanced legislation that would bar foreign state ownership of newspapers and newsmagazines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French and Jillian Weinberger
title: Why Haley Supporters Should Turn to Biden, Not Trump
description: David French on why “MAGA will not accommodate Reagan conservatism.”
content: Shortly after Nikki Haley exited the presidential race, Joe Biden issued a statement welcoming her supporters to the Democratic Party. In this audio essay, Times Opinion columnist David French implores Haley fans — specifically Reagan Republicans — to join the Democratic coalition. “If you want to preserve Reagan conservatism and its ideals, its temperament, its character, its ideology,” French says, “the best way to preserve it is by ending Donald Trump’s stranglehold on the G.O.P.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Philippe de Gaulle, Admiral and Son of Charles de Gaulle, Dies at 102
description: His exploits in World War II and later in Algeria and Indochina were not enough for him emerge from the shadow of his father, for whom a thousand streets in France are named.
content: Adm. Philippe de Gaulle, the oldest child of the French wartime leader and former president Charles de Gaulle, died on Wednesday in Paris. He was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Oil Fields Release Far More Methane Than Thought, Study Finds
description: In parts of New Mexico, more than 9 percent of all natural gas produced goes into the atmosphere, where it acts as a powerful greenhouse gas.
content: Oil and gas producers in major oil fields across the United States may be emitting three times as much planet-warming methane gas as official estimates, according to new research published Wednesday, the latest study to suggest that emissions from the fossil fuel sector may be grossly undercounted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meaghan Tobin
title: China Condemns U.S. Proposal to Force the Sale of TikTok
description: The foreign ministry accused Washington of “resorting to hegemonic moves” ahead of a House vote on a bill aimed at ByteDance, TikTok’s Chinese parent company.
content: China on Wednesday condemned U.S. lawmakers’ push to force the Chinese parent company of TikTok to sell the popular short video platform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Top French University Faces Yet Another Crisis as Leader Resigns
description: Mathias Vicherat, the director of Sciences Po, and his former partner are expected to face trial over mutual accusations of violence. His resignation prolongs years of tumult in the school’s highest ranks.
content: One of France’s most elite universities found itself without a leader for the second time in just three years on Wednesday after its director, Mathias Vicherat, resigned to face a court case over accusations of domestic violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Donald Trump and Joe Biden Clinch Their Party Nominations
description: After sweeping another set of contests on Tuesday, the former president and the current president have won the delegates they need for a long-anticipated rematch.
content: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday secured the delegates necessary to clinch their parties’ presidential nominations, according to The Associated Press, cementing a general election rematch in November months in the making.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang W. Lee
title: A Japanese Festival of Fire and Spirits
description: During Setsubun celebrations in Kyoto, demons and bad luck are banished as people prepare for the start of the new year.
content: As the sun peeked out from the cloudy sky in Kyoto, Japan, monks wearing vests trimmed with pompoms and the black box-like headdresses known as tokin were being quizzed in front of Mibu Dera, one of the oldest temples in the city. These were the Yamabushi (mountain hermits), part of a Buddhist sect known as the Shugendō.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Family drama in the Garden State
description: Two of New Jersey’s three statewide offices could be held by people living in the same mansion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: TikTok’s Security Threats Go Beyond the Scope of House Legislation
description: The risks have less to do with who owns the app than who writes the code and algorithms that make TikTok tick.
content: In a capital where Republicans and Democrats agree on virtually nothing, it was notable when the House overwhelmingly declared on Wednesday that TikTok poses such a grave risk to national security that it must be forced to sell its U.S. operations to a non-Chinese owner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Four Years On, Covid Has Reshaped Life for Many Americans
description: Covid was declared a national emergency on March 13, 2020. Even as the threat of severe illness and death has faded, the pandemic’s effects linger.
content: Jessie Thompson, a 36-year-old mother of two in Chicago, is reminded of the Covid-19 pandemic every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Sergey Ponomarev
title: From Moscow to Mumbai: Russia Pivots South for Trade
description: Once dependent on Europe for trade, Russia has been forging new routes that will allow it to skirt Western restrictions. A planned railway through Iran could be key for those ambitions.
content: For centuries, trade with Europe was the main pillar of Russia’s economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Ex-Boss Sexually Harassed Me. Do I Owe Him Credit When Sharing Past Work?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to uphold a professional expectation after leaving an abusive workplace.
content: I’m a designer who started my first full-time job a few years ago at a small branding studio. I worked under its creative director, who also happened to be the studio’s owner and its only other full-time staff member. Shortly after starting, he began harassing me. I was considerably younger than he and had little professional experience; I chalked up his behavior to loneliness and the casualness of the industry. I also blamed myself. Still, the harassment persisted until, two years in, I mustered the courage to confront him, asking for firmer professional boundaries at work. A few months later, he fired me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: ‘Devastated’ Widow Says M.T.A. Workers Shared Photos of Slain Husband
description: Jakeba Dockery says graphic photos of her husband, Richard Henderson, after he was shot on a No. 3 train were shared online in violation of New York’s civil rights law.
content: The morning after her husband was shot and killed while trying to break up a fight on the subway, Jakeba Dockery was sitting at home in Brooklyn, still in shock, when she received a text from a family friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Some Black Voters Are Souring on Democrats. It May Be Part of a Natural Drift.
description: There are signs that Black voters are inching closer to the patterns of other demographic groups.
content: “I almost voted for him,” Felicia Lowe, a 55-year-old Black woman, told me on Tuesday as she exited the polling place at the Metropolitan branch of the Fulton County Library.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: ‘Apples Never Fall’ Review: A Drama Wrapped in a Mystery Inside a Formula
description: This Peacock mini-series about a bitter family and a missing woman is TV’s latest adaptation of a novel by the author of “Big Little Lies.”
content: “Apples Never Fall,” premiering Thursday on Peacock, is the third Liane Moriarty book to be adapted for television, following HBO’s “Big Little Lies” and Hulu’s “Nine Perfect Strangers.” But if you told me it was the 10th, I’d believe you, given how familiar it all feels. The seven-episode mini-series is so well-oiled and unsurprising, it just glides on by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Yes, the Internet Is Broken, but What Does a Fix Look Like?
description: There’s no obvious way to reclaim control over the web from Big Tech, but technologists are trying.
content: Tuesday was the 35th anniversary of the day that Tim Berners-Lee of the European Organization for Nuclear Research wrote the memo proposing what became the World Wide Web. Queen Elizabeth II knighted him in 2004 for his achievement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: Bipartisan Tax Bill Is Stuck in Senate Limbo After Broad House Approval
description: The measure would expand the child tax credit and restore three popular business tax breaks. But Senate Republicans have rejected the existing package as elections loom.
content: A bipartisan bill to expand the child tax credit and reinstate a set of business tax breaks has stalled in the Senate after winning overwhelming approval in the House, as Republicans balk at legislation they regard as too generous to low-income families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Could ‘Mitchell-Lama 2.0’ Help New York’s Housing Crisis?
description: The State Senate has proposed a new version of a popular program from the 1950s that built affordable housing.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out about plans to address the housing crisis, not just in New York City but statewide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Trailing Trump in Polls, Biden Can Be More Bullish in One Battleground
description: The president faces lagging energy in many key states. But in Wisconsin, which he will visit on Wednesday, rolling clashes over abortion rights and democracy have kept Democratic voters fired up.
content: Across most of the battleground states, President Biden’s re-election campaign is trailed by worrisome polling, gripes about a slow ramp-up and Democratic calls to show more urgency to the threat posed by former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: Kate Middleton’s Story Is About So Much More Than Kate Middleton
description: The scandal is another blatant display of royal double standards.
content: “Where Is Kate Middleton?” yet another headline blared on Monday. The public speculation after her unspecified abdominal surgery, long withdrawal from appearances and dubious publicity photo has gotten so intense that reasonable people may want to roll their eyes and tune it out. Can’t we just wish her well and leave her alone?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Why Do Whales Go Through Menopause?
description: A new study argues that the change brought these females an evolutionary advantage — and perhaps did the same for humans.
content: Menopause is all too familiar to women, but in other species it’s remarkably rare. Last year, scientists reported that females in a single population of chimpanzees live long past their reproductive years. But aside from chimps and humans, researchers have found clear evidence of menopause in only five species — all of them whales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Artists and Speakers Withdraw From SXSW Over U.S. Military’s Support of Israel
description: About 80 musical acts, conference speakers and sponsors have pulled out of the festival in Austin to protest sponsorship by the U.S. military, which has lent support to Israel in the war in Gaza.
content: Dozens of musicians and panelists have withdrawn from the South by Southwest Conference and Festivals in Austin, Texas, to protest sponsorship by the U.S. Army and defense companies as pressure grows against the U.S. military’s support of Israel’s war against Hamas in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: Will She Make the Next Birkin?
description: A bag designer at Hermès has the fun and formidable challenge of creating a new icon. No presh.
content: “The bag, it carries your things and carries your secrets,” Priscila Alexandre Spring said. The 43-year-old creative director of leather goods at Hermès sat in her office in Pantin, just outside of Paris, explaining what she liked about designing bags — in particular, the relationship between “your private life and your exterior life.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: With Lackluster Growth, Dating Apps Are in Need of a Spark
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 13, 2024.
content: “Paying for it makes it feel a little skeezy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Pro-Israel Lobby Faces Challenges Amid Gaza War and Shifting Politics
description: AIPAC, long influential with both parties in Washington, is drawing criticism from Democrats for trying to defeat incumbents while it struggles to move aid for Israel through Congress.
content: AIPAC, the pro-Israel group that has long been among Washington’s most powerful lobbying forces, is facing intense challenges as it seeks to maintain bipartisan support for Israel amid the war in Gaza — even as it alienates some Democrats with its increasingly aggressive political tactics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Dallas Seavey Wins Record Sixth Iditarod Despite Moose-Gutting Penalty
description: Seavey won the sled dog race after a harrowing close encounter with a moose, and a punishment for how he handled it.
content: Dallas Seavey won his record sixth Iditarod sled dog race on Tuesday, despite an eventful race that included a penalty for failing to properly gut a moose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: The Actress Who Looks Out for Denmark
description: Hunting murderers, delivering babies or guarding inmates, Sofie Grabol plays women who try to keep their country safe.
content: If you watch much Danish television — and that is an option these days, wherever you happen to live — a question rises: How would Denmark function without Sofie Grabol?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Time-Saving Tips for Using Your Phone as a … Telephone
description: The latest smartphone software includes tools to help you more easily connect with the people you want to contact — and avoid those you don’t.
content: With everything a smartphone can do these days, it’s often easy to overlook one of the device’s most basic functions: voice calls. Communicating by telephone has become more complicated in a world of robocalls and automated voice trees, but your phone may already have the tools to make talking to people (or not) easier. Here are a few suggestions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: A Corvette, Swimsuit Shots and a Trip to Mongolia: Biden Offers a Tour of His Life
description: Transcripts of five hours of interviews with the special counsel released this week reveal a president with a lot on his mind and a storehouse of stories to tell.
content: They were there to talk about classified documents, but somehow President Biden’s mind had turned to Mongolia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $550,000 Homes in New York, Ohio and New Jersey
description: An A-frame cabin in Greene County, a renovated bungalow in Columbus and a 1911 home outside Philadelphia.
content: This house is five minutes from Prattsville, a Greene County town with a diner, a tavern and a grocery store, and a 10-minute drive from a number of Catskill Mountains hiking and biking trails. Hunter Mountain, a popular ski resort, is 20 minutes away. The town of Catskill, on the banks of the Hudson River, is a 45-minute drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: These Workers Are Risking Their Lives to Restore Gaza’s Phone Network
description: Telecommunications infrastructure has been devastated in the territory, largely preventing Palestinians from calling for help, coordinating the delivery of aid and communicating with family abroad.
content: When Mohammed Sweirky prepared to leave for a work trip in January to repair telecommunications infrastructure that had been destroyed in northern Gaza, his wife and children pleaded with him not to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Zach Montague
title: Inside the Blunders That Plunged the College Admission Season Into Disarray
description: The Education Department was supposed to make applying for federal financial aid easier. Instead, it got worse.
content: There were just days left to process a batch of federal financial aid applications when Education Department officials made a fateful discovery: 70,000 emails from students all over the country, containing reams of essential data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikole Hannah-Jones
title: The ‘Colorblindness’ Trap: How a Civil Rights Ideal Got Hijacked
description: The fall of affirmative action is part of a 50-year campaign to roll back racial progress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Hopkins
title: What’s the Best Way to Get Rid of a Hangnail?
description: These pesky skin tears can be a huge pain. Here’s what to do if you get one, and how to prevent hangnails in the first place.
content: Q: I get frequent hangnails — and they hurt. Is there anything I can do to speed up the healing process?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Olivia Munn Had Double Mastectomy After Breast Cancer Diagnosis
description: Munn said she was given the diagnosis last April, two months after negative results on a test that checked for 90 cancer genes.
content: The actress Olivia Munn said on Wednesday that she had been given a diagnosis of an aggressive form of breast cancer last year and soon after had a double mastectomy as part of her treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: A Rare Inside Look at Human Smuggling on the Border
description: In “Soldiers and Kings,” the anthropologist Jason De León interviews smugglers, arguing that they are victims of poverty and violence, even as they exploit the humans in their care.
content: The anthropologist Jason De León dedicated five years to studying migrants who tried to make the deadly crossing into the United States over the Sonoran Desert, hiking hundreds of miles of the trails himself so that he could better understand the dangers faced by the people he interviewed. His intensive fieldwork made its way into his 2015 book, “The Land of Open Graves,” and in 2017 he was granted a MacArthur fellowship. Yet he could see that he was still missing a crucial part of the story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Under Armour’s Founder Will Return as C.E.O.
description: Kevin Plank, the sports apparel company’s controlling shareholder, will seek to reinvigorate the struggling brand.
content: Under Armour, the sports apparel company, said on Wednesday that its founder, Kevin Plank, would return as chief executive, in a leadership shake-up that will seek to revitalize the struggling brand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: A New Plan to Hire Thousands of Workers to Help N.Y.C. Families in Need
description: Adrienne Adams, the speaker of the City Council, described the initiative in a speech that highlighted policies aimed at making New York a more affordable place to live.
content: Adrienne Adams, the speaker of the City Council, announced on Wednesday an effort to help hire New Yorkers for important but unfilled city jobs. The plan, which she described during her third State of the City address at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is intended to improve services for New Yorkers and provide access to good-paying jobs that will help people remain in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Should China Own TikTok?
description: Inside the bipartisan effort to end Chinese ownership of the app.
content: To understand why the House of Representatives will vote today on a bipartisan bill to force TikTok’s Chinese parent company to sell the platform, it helps to look at a few recent news stories:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Thursday Briefing: U.S. Targets TikTok
description: Also, aid to northern Gaza and whimsical wooden automatons
content: The House of Representatives passed a bill meant to force ByteDance, the Chinese internet company, to sell TikTok within six months to a buyer that satisfies the U.S. government — or face a ban in the country. The vote was the latest development in a cold war between the U.S. and China over the control of valuable technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leila Mottley
title: Read Your Way Through the San Francisco Bay Area
description: The Bay Area has had many lives. The Oakland novelist Leila Mottley shares books that paint a picture of the city that lives and breathes today.
content: The San Francisco Bay Area is anything but a monoculture. Go to San Francisco, hop across the Bay Bridge into Oakland, then head up into Richmond or down to Hayward, and the landscape around you — the people, the food, the particular cadence of walk and talk — will morph. To read the Bay Area is to traverse the spectrum of a place that has had many lives, simultaneously a landing spot for people seeking sanctuary and a place that has repelled the very people who have shaped it and loved it most.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: Ramadan’s Start Brings ‘No Joy’ to Palestinians in the West Bank
description: One woman said she had a hard time sitting down for meals knowing that many in Gaza were starving: “I keep asking myself, did they eat?”
content: Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank are welcoming Ramadan with little of the usual cheer. Amid Israel’s continuing attacks in Gaza and rising violence in the West Bank, the holy month’s festive decorations and celebratory mood are being replaced by feelings of helplessness and despair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Rennie Harris and Chicago House to the Rescue
description: Hubbard Street Dance Chicago presents the first of two programs at the Joyce Theater, including a sparkling New York premiere by the hip-hop choreographer Rennie Harris.
content: When a repertory company comes to town with two programs, and one has a Rennie Harris dance on it, choose that. This Philadelphia hip-hop choreographer is a treasure and so are his dances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: In the Fight Over N.Y.C. Sidewalks, Tree Beds Are the Smallest Frontier
description: In a city with little private green space, tree beds on public streets have become coveted territory. But who gets to decide how they’re used?
content: Over 660,000 trees line the streets of New York City, and the beds around them take up more than 400 acres, according to a city estimate. While many people just walk by the rectangular openings in the sidewalk from which the trees spring — or, worse, use the spaces as trash cans and doggy litter boxes — others lay claim, unofficially, to these pocket-size patches of land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak
title: Brazil’s Clashing Goals: Protect the Amazon and Pump Lots More Oil
description: State-owned Petrobras could soon be the world’s third-biggest oil producer, in stark contrast to the country’s promises to fight climate change and slow Amazon destruction.
content: Through his office window, the head of Brazil’s state-run oil company looked out at the cluttered landscape of Rio de Janeiro. Looking back at him, across the city’s run-down high-rises, was the looming statue of Christ the Redeemer. Hawks circled an overflowing trash heap. Plumes of smoke rose from a blaze in a hillside shantytown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Slams Former Special Counsel’s Conclusions
description: Colbert objected to Robert K. Hur calling President Biden a “well-meaning, elderly man with a poor memory” in a report on the handling of classified documents.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: With Humor, Kobi Libii Gives His Characters a Different Superpower
description: The writer and director of “The American Society of Magical Negroes” has made a satire that may feel primed to be provocative. He responds to some of the discourse.
content: In “The American Society of Magical Negroes,” the writer-director Kobi Libii’s debut feature film opening March 15, a mysterious group of Black people possess superpowers. But unlike Black Panther or Miles Morales’s Spider-Man, this group doesn’t fight criminals or take on villains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Germany Looks to Stop the Far Right From Assuming Power
description: Mainstream parties are changing laws to protect government institutions. Critics say the changes risk undermining democracy.
content: For Germany — a country that knows something about how extremists can hijack a government — the surging popularity of the far right has forced an awkward question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Family Dollar to Close Nearly 1,000 Stores
description: The chain has struggled for years. Its parent company, Dollar Tree, cited inflation, theft and reduced government benefits as challenges that had prompted the closings.
content: Family Dollar will close nearly 1,000 stores, a move its executives say is a result of declining sales and economic headwinds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: An Indulgent, Crunchy and Molten-Cheese-Covered Chicken Delight
description: The classic chicken Parmesan gets a Za’atar and melted halloumi twist.
content: The act of triple-dipping goes back to my early years. Three shallow bowls: one with flour, another with beaten egg, the third with breadcrumbs. It’s as familiar as the 1970s brown Formica kitchen counter and the avocado-green fridge doors, with their faux-wood handles that would inevitably be smudged with sticky flour paste as I reached for an extra egg or two.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Seattle University to Receive $300 Million Art Collection
description: The hotel developer Richard Hedreen is donating more than 200 artworks, and $25 million in seed money, in honor of his wife, Betty, an alumna.
content: Seattle University is making plans for a new art museum, thanks to a gift of a $300 million art collection and $25 million in seed money from a donor, the university trustees announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: New U.S. Arms for Ukraine Will Help, for a Little While
description: The $300 million package will help hold off the Russians for a few weeks, analysts say, but without far more Ukraine may go on losing ground.
content: The $300 million in new weaponry the United States is sending to Ukraine, the first American military aid package in months, will help Ukraine hold off Russian troops for a few weeks, analysts say, but it will not change the overall situation on the battlefield, where Moscow currently has the advantage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Israeli Strike Kills a Hamas Operative in Lebanon
description: It was the latest in a string of targeted killings there of what Israel has called senior figures from both Hezbollah and Hamas.
content: The Israeli military said on Wednesday that it had killed a senior Hamas operative in an airstrike in southern Lebanon, the latest in a series of targeted killings there following the deadly Hamas-led attacks against Israel on Oct. 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike McIntire
title: Michigan Vows to Destroy Buyback Guns After Resale Uproar
description: Police agencies in Michigan and elsewhere were handing off surrendered firearms to companies that resold the parts in gun kits.
content: Michigan will no longer allow guns marked for destruction to be sold online as parts — a change prompted by public anger over revelations that firearms turned in through buyback programs were not being destroyed as promised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Neil Young Will Return to Spotify, Ending Protest of Joe Rogan
description: The rock musician removed his songs from the streamer in 2022 to protest coronavirus podcast episodes, but reversed course in light of the show’s wider distribution.
content: Neil Young will return his music to Spotify, two years after withdrawing it in protest over the podcast host Joe Rogan’s shows about Covid-19, the veteran rock musician announced on his website Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Texting Styles
description: Are you usually quick — or slow — to reply? How much does your response time depend on who you’re messaging?
content: Imagine someone messages you at a quarter to 1 on a Saturday night after not answering your last message two days ago. How are you responding?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon, Lars Dolder, Victoria Kim and Michael Levenson
title: Israel Allows Aid Directly Into North Gaza, Raising Hopes for More
description: The World Food Program delivery, containing food for 25,000 people, was the first since Oct. 7 to go directly from Israel into the northern Gaza Strip, where many people are at risk of starvation.
content: Israel has allowed a small convoy carrying food to enter northern Gaza directly through an Israeli border crossing for the first time since the war began on Oct. 7, as global pressure intensifies to let more desperately needed aid into the territory, where hundreds of thousands are at risk of starvation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Russia fires the leader of its navy.
content: The Kremlin fired its top naval commander after a series of devastating attacks by Ukraine on Russia’s Black Sea Fleet, according to Ukrainian and Western officials and reports in Russian and Western news outlets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann and Madison Malone Kircher
title: Outdoor Voices to Close All Stores This Week
description: The athleisure retailer will go online only, according to employees who were surprised by the announcement.
content: Outdoor Voices, an athletic apparel company, is closing all its stores on Sunday, according to four employees at four different stores who were granted anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss the news.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 13, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, March 13, 2024.
content: An article on Saturday about online betting on Oscar winners described incorrectly an estimate provided by the American Gaming Association. The amount, $10.26 billion, reflects an estimation of the legal revenue of online sports books in Oscars betting, not the total that  Americans spent in online wagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Ormont Blumberg
title: The Actor Who Rides the Subway to the Oscars
description: Ed Begley Jr. has made a tradition of taking public transportation to the Academy Awards. And, like many commuters, he wears sensible shoes.
content: Ed Begley Jr. could be described as Hollywood royalty: The actor is a son of another actor, Ed Begley, who won a best supporting actor Oscar in 1963.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King and Michael C. Bender
title: R.N.C. Shutting Down Community Centers Aimed at Minority Outreach
description: While the new chairman says the party still plans to use the centers, an overhaul of G.O.P. operations continues as Donald Trump’s allies take over.
content: The Republican National Committee, days after electing new leadership and overhauling its presidential campaign operation, is shuttering all of the community centers it established for minority outreach nationwide and laying off their staffs, according to two people briefed on the plans, a move that could impede Republicans’ efforts to court voters of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Happens Next With TikTok?
description: Even though legislation is moving forward, our video apps won’t disappear any time soon.
content: What happens next with TikTok?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joy Neumeyer
title: There Is Something Putin Can’t Control
description: As “The Master and Margarita” shows, power never totally succeeds in shaping art to its ends.
content: According to “The Master and Margarita,” Mikhail Bulgakov’s celebrated novel about the devil’s visit to Stalinist Moscow, “manuscripts don’t burn.” This famous phrase became a shorthand for art’s supposed ability to triumph over repression. Today, Bulgakov’s formula is being put to the test once again in Russia, where a new film adaptation of the book has caused a scandal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Jury Deliberates in James Crumbley’s Michigan School Shooting Trial
description: Witness testimony and closing arguments ended on Wednesday. Mr. Crumbley faces involuntary manslaughter charges for the four students killed by his son.
content: James Crumbley “did nothing” to prevent his son from carrying out Michigan’s deadliest school shooting, prosecutors said in closing arguments on Wednesday, while his defense attorney argued that he was unaware of his son’s troubled mental state or plans to attack his schoolmates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Is the End of the Filibuster Near?
description: The Senate’s signature procedural tactic is losing some of its staunchest defenders in Senators Kyrsten Sinema and Joe Manchin, leaving its future in doubt.
content: Time may be finally running out on the filibuster, the signature dilatory tactic in the Senate embraced by some as a protector of minority rights and reviled by others as an outdated weapon of partisan obstruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Los Angeles Opera’s Music Director to Step Down After 20 Years
description: James Conlon, who has conducted more performances with the company than anyone else, will step down from his post in 2026.
content: The year 2026 will mark James Conlon’s 20th anniversary as music director of the Los Angeles Opera. That seemed to him like it would be the right time to step down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Matison
title: 5 Getaways That Reinvent Eco-Tourism
description: From the Columbia River Gorge to the Chesapeake Bay, these retreats provide educational and volunteer experiences for travelers not only wanting to reconnect with nature, but to give back.
content: Hotels and glamping sites touting sustainability practices and nature-based activities have proliferated throughout the United States in the last decade, finding financial success by offering guests a let-nature-nurture-you wellness experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Why a Sale of TikTok Would Not Be Easy
description: As legislation moves ahead that could eventually mandate a sale by the Chinese parent company ByteDance, hurdles include finding buyers.
content: Legislation that could eventually mandate a sale of TikTok is moving forward. But any kind of divestiture by its Chinese parent company, ByteDance, is likely to prove challenging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Why We Gave Up on the Future
description: The rise of political nostalgia isn’t just about “vibes.”
content: In America, now, we are living at “the end of the future,” the historian Steve Fraser wrote this month in Jacobin, surveying the country’s political landscape and finding it pretty exhausted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: They Sell Candy Instead of Going to School. New York Isn’t Stopping Them.
description: Letting children work in the train system during school hours breaks several laws and rules. But a series of agencies said it was not their place to stop the practice.
content: On a subway platform in the Bronx recently, a girl in a puffer coat strolled past passengers with a basket of M&M’s, Kit Kats and Trident gum slung across her shoulder. She looked to be 7 or 8.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Sex Abuse Inquiry Poses Leadership Test for World Bank’s Ajay Banga
description: The bank is facing scrutiny as it debates how to compensate victims of abuse at Kenyan schools that it was financing.
content: At the World Bank’s annual meetings last year in Morocco, the organization’s new president, Ajay Banga, outlined a sweeping vision for how he wanted to rid the world of poverty while keeping the planet habitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: How Will I Know if My Braise Is Ready?
description: In the second installment of Ask Kenji, the cookbook author Kenji López-Alt tackles tough questions about tender meat.
content: In this column, Ask Kenji, the cookbook author Kenji López-Alt answers your questions. This week, he tackles tough questions about yielding tender meat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin, in Pre-Election Messaging, Is Less Strident on Nuclear War
description: The Russian leader struck a softer tone about nuclear weapons in an interview with state television. But he warned that Russia was ready to strike if its “sovereignty and independence” were threatened.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia took a less strident tone on the possibility of nuclear war in an interview released on Wednesday, an apparent attempt to bolster his domestic image as a guarantor of stability before the Russian presidential election this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Weeknight Chicken Marbella, Briny and Lush With Olives and Prunes
description: Rick Martinez’s streamlined recipe updates a 1980s favorite for 2024 weeknights.
content: My parents’ initiation into elevated home cooking came by way of Julia Child’s soufflés and coq au vin, but for me the gateway was phyllo triangles and carrot cake from “The Silver Palate Cookbook.” That milestone book, by Julee Rosso and Sheila Lukins, made cooking seem easy, playful and fun, with a lighthearted tone and recipes that captured the fresh and casually stylish zeitgeist of the early 1980s. For better or worse, it introduced an entire generation to arugula, raspberry vinegar and homemade walnut-basil pesto (that last one whirled in a blender).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Malaysia Rises as Crucial Link in Chip Supply Chain
description: U.S. and European companies looking to diversify from China are expanding around Southeast Asia, a sign of how geopolitics is reshaping tech manufacturing.
content: Construction cranes still surround the brand-spanking new plant in Kulim’s industrial park in Malaysia. But inside, legions of workers hired by the Austrian tech giant AT&S are already gearing up to produce at full capacity by year’s end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Trending at the Oscars, Brooches for Men
description: The brooch has shed its granny’s jewel box connotations and is making a comeback as a must-have accessory for guys.
content: War, labor strikes and a thorny political season made scant inroads at the 2024 Academy Awards, where branding trumped protest and jeweled ornaments far outnumbered cease-fire pins. As the most traditional of award shows returned to its roots as a glorified trade affair (ginned up 96 years ago as a way of pacifying above-the-line talent in the wake of the unionizing then gaining a foothold in moviedom), praise was near universal for the return to old Hollywood glamour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Álvaro Santana-Acuña
title: Would It Really Be Better to Never See Gabriel García Márquez’s Final Book?
description: We all benefit when works by great artists that are marked for destruction are instead preserved.
content: When the writer Gabriel García Márquez, the author of “One Hundred Years of Solitude” and other classic novels, died nearly 10 years ago, he left behind an unfinished novel, “Until August.” The novel was published this week, unleashing a backlash from scholars, writers and fans who’ve taken exception not with the novel itself, but rather with what they see as an act of betrayal that endangers García Márquez’s legacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Allure of Getting Dressed
description: It’s a genuine trend. Just look at Hedi Slimane’s Celine.
content: A full week after the end of the fashion season, Hedi Slimane of Celine released his fall women’s wear collection — as a video. But while he may have been going his own way with timing and format, in one way he was right on trend: Rather than offering up yet another cool-girl-in-the-city collection (trench coats, jeans, blazers, vintage slip dresses), he swerved in an entirely different direction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Lawyer, Author and TikTok Star Spent 72 Years in an Iron Lung
description: Paul Alexander, who died at 78, was paralyzed with polio at age 6 and relied on the machine to breathe. Still, he was able to earn a law degree, write a book and, late in life, build a following on TikTok.
content: After he was paralyzed by polio at age 6, Paul Alexander was confined for much of his life to a yellow iron lung that kept him alive. He was not expected to survive after that diagnosis, and even when he beat those odds, his life was mostly constrained by a machine in which he could not move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno and Yan Zhuang
title: Space One Rocket Explodes Seconds After Launch in Japan
description: The Japanese company hoped to become the country’s first private business to put a satellite into orbit. The failed launch was its inaugural flight.
content: The first rocket launched by the Japanese start-up Space One exploded seconds after takeoff on Wednesday, denting its ambition to become the country’s first private company to put a satellite into orbit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: gauzy
description: This word has appeared in 46 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word gauzy has appeared in 46 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 30 in “In the Faroe Islands, Art, Food and Fashion Take a Cue From Nature” by Jeanine Barone:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Many Aid Deliveries for Gaza Are Rejected for ‘Dual-Use’ Items, Groups Say
description: One truck was turned away because it contained scissors in medical kits for children, a U.N. official said. Israeli authorities accused the official of lying.
content: A U.N. official said a truck carrying aid was turned around in Gaza this week because it contained scissors included in medical kits for children, calling attention to what aid groups have said is a laborious Israeli inspection process that is slowing down crucial humanitarian assistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Weeknight Skillet Chicken Dinner, Rich With Greens
description: This forgiving and adaptable weeknight dinner stars tender chicken thighs, braising greens and whole garlic cloves.
content: If the overabundance of root vegetables like sunchokes, black radishes and kohlrabies the size of my head is the late-winter scourge of my C.S.A., the steady supply of braising greens is its redemption. No matter how many bunches of curly kale, sturdy collard greens and steely chard arrive each week, there’s always a place on my table for their floppy, verdant magic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: R.F.K. Jr. Will Reveal Running Mate on March 26, His Campaign Says
description: The independent presidential candidate’s shortlist of potential running mates includes the N.F.L. quarterback Aaron Rodgers.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. will announce the vice-presidential pick for his independent presidential bid at an event in Oakland, Calif., on March 26, his campaign said on Wednesday, a move that comes amid swirling speculation about his potential running mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Israeli forces make a lethal strike on a U.N. aid warehouse in Rafah.
description: The strike kil
content: The Israeli military confirmed that it had bombed an aid warehouse in Rafah in southern Gaza on Wednesday, saying it had “precisely targeted” and killed a Hamas commander in an attack that the United Nations said also killed at least one aid worker and injured 22 others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago, Travis Diehl and Martha Schwendener
title: Dozens of Artists, 3 Critics: Who’s Afraid of the Whitney Biennial 2024?
description: “Even Better Than the Real Thing” will go down as a well-intentioned edition of the perpetually debated show. Will it go down as a notable one?
content: The Whitney Biennial, New York’s most prominent showcase of new American (or American-ish) art, thrives on argument: in print, in comment threads, in barrooms and sometimes in the galleries themselves. Its 81st edition opens Thursday to museum members and to the public on March 20, and it introduces a “dissonant chorus” — in the phrase of Ligia Lewis, a participating artist and choreographer — of young talents and veteran practitioners. We sent a dissonant chorus of our own to the Whitney Museum of American Art: three critics, each writing separately, on the highs and lows of the exhibition everyone will have an opinion about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikole Hannah-Jones
title: Five Takeaways From Nikole Hannah-Jones’s Essay on the ‘Colorblindness’ Trap
description: How a 50-year campaign has undermined the progress of the civil rights movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Geert Wilders Says He Will Forgo Becoming Dutch Prime Minister
description: Mr. Wilders, a hard-right icon, won the last elections decisively. His announcement may help facilitate the creation of a right-wing government in the Netherlands.
content: Geert Wilders, the hard-right politician who won a shocking victory in the last Dutch elections, said on Wednesday that he was willing to forgo becoming the prime minister of the Netherlands — for now — in an effort to increase the chances of forming a right-wing coalition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The House Dealt TikTok a Blow
description: Also, this college admission season has been a disaster. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: A huge bipartisan majority of the House of Representatives voted today to pass a bill that would force TikTok’s Chinese owner either to sell the popular video app or face a ban in the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Love Pi Day? You Can Thank San Francisco for That.
description: The celebration of March 14 began as a weird Bay Area tradition.
content: Tomorrow is Pi Day, the annual celebration of the ever-intriguing mathematical constant denoted by the Greek letter π. Children in math classes across America will soon be discussing the magic of a circle’s circumference and, perhaps more memorably, devouring delicious pies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Close Call
description: Drew Schmenner proves that constructing puzzles is his forte.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

title: Autopsy Shows Nex Benedict Died by Suicide
description: A medical examiner found evidence of a toxic mix of drugs in the 16-year-old nonbinary high school student in Oklahoma, who died one day after an altercation in a girls’ bathroom.
content: Nex Benedict, a 16-year-old nonbinary student in Oklahoma who died a day after a physical altercation in a high school girls’ bathroom, died as a result of suicide, according to an autopsy report released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: E.U. Removes Russian Tech Tycoon From Sanctions List
description: Yandex’s co-founder, Arkady Volozh, received rare sanctions relief after condemning Russia’s war and severing ties to the country.
content: The European Union has lifted sanctions against a Russian technology tycoon, in a rare break from a policy of punishing the country’s elites for the invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Deadly Journey on the U.S.-Mexico Border
description: The day before President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump both visited the U.S.-Mexico border, I traveled to the spot where Mr. Trump was scheduled to speak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Anna Wintour Sings! (Sort Of.)
description: In a trio of shows about prominent women in media, Ryan Raftery portrays the Vogue editor, as well as Martha Stewart and Kris Jenner.
content: In his main job, Ryan Raftery works in the New York offices of LVMH, doing talent recruitment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Sapna Maheshwari
title: What to Know About the TikTok Bill That the House Passed
description: The bill, which would force TikTok’s Chinese parent to sell the popular social media app, faces a difficult path in the Senate.
content: House lawmakers on Wednesday approved legislation meant to force ByteDance, the Chinese internet company, to sell its wildly popular social media app TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Heirs Awarded Nazi-Looted Art Are Still Waiting, 17 Years Later
description: A Dutch panel ruled in 2007 to return the painting to a Jewish family, but a notary handling the restitution for the government says he still doesn’t have all the right documents.
content: In a museum storage depot in Amersfoort, the Netherlands, a 17th-century painting by a Dutch old master is packed away, unseen and unappreciated. author: By Philip Galanes
title: How Do I Get My Unemployed Brother Out of Our Father’s House?
description: Four years after being laid off, a man in his 50s is still relying on his father, who just moved into an assisted living facility, for support and housing. Should his sister say something?
content: My brother, in his 50s, was a successful professional for many years. He was laid off from his job four years ago and has been unable to find regular employment since then. He has now depleted his savings. He says it’s challenging to find work in his field as an older person, so I suggested taking a lower-paying job — in any field — to support himself, but he doesn’t appear to be looking for work. And ever since we moved our father to an assisted living facility, my brother has been living in his house. Keeping the house is an unnecessary financial burden on our father, and my brother has agreed that we should sell it. But every time we set a timetable for doing so, he asks for a delay. I’m worried about what will happen if he never finds another place to live. Should I say something to him?
